Smart grid implementation represents a crucial advancement in energy management, integrating advanced technologies to optimize electricity production, distribution, and consumption. As highlighted by Okedu et al. (2019), GCC countries, including Saudi Arabia, face unique challenges and opportunities in smart grid deployment, particularly in integrating AI-based forecasting and IoT-based monitoring systems. Recent research by Khan et al. (2023) demonstrates how smart grid technologies enable two-way communication between suppliers and consumers, promoting more efficient resource use and seamless integration of renewable energy sources. This integration is crucial for Saudi Arabia\'s energy transition strategy, where production can be adapted to demand in real time, helping reduce energy losses and minimize fossil fuel dependence. Building on the cost-benefit analysis framework developed by Alaqeel & Suryanarayanan (2019), this project will evaluate both direct financial impacts and broader macroeconomic effects of smart grid implementation. Their research indicates that long-term economic gains from reduced transmission losses and enhanced energy efficiency outweigh initial infrastructure costs. The project will utilize advanced modeling techniques, including AI and machine learning approaches. As demonstrated by Almohaimeed (2023) in their university-based microgrid study, these technologies can significantly improve grid stability and efficiency. Using historical energy load data, weather forecasting, and machine learning techniques such as Markov models and neural networks (as suggested by Islam & Ali, 2024), the smart grid will continuously learn and support the development of an efficient energy management system. The environmental impact assessment will build on Sajwani et al.\'s (2023) findings, which showed that renewable-powered smart grids can lead to substantial CO₂ emissions reductions. This aligns with Selim & Alshareef\'s (2025) emphasis on the importance of green finance mechanisms and public-private partnerships in funding smart grid projects. The study acknowledges the challenges identified by Alanazi & Alenezi (2024), particularly regarding substantial upfront investment needs in infrastructure (advanced metering systems, sensors, software, and communication technologies) and policy adaptation. A comprehensive cost-benefit analysis will integrate both energy efficiency at the microeconomic level and the aggregated impact on greenhouse emissions at the macroeconomic level, contributing to Saudi Arabia\'s NZE ambitions achievement. **Objective (600-1500)** The project aims to develop a comprehensive analysis of smart grid implementation potential in the Asir region through the assessment of key technology packages and international benchmarks, the analysis of current infrastructure and regulatory framework and the development of implementation scenarios. To this end, we will: 1. Evaluate economic implications with detailed cost-benefit analysis, assessment of investment models and funding mechanisms, and the analysis of public-private partnership opportunities. 2. Assess environmental impact by quantifying potential greenhouse gas reductions, modeling contributions to Saudi Arabia\'s NZE 2060 goals, and developing AI-powered energy management models. 3. Formulate policy recommendations for Smart grid adoption framework, Investment and funding mechanisms, Regional and national implementation strategies The project will focus on the Asir region as a case study, with findings scaled to assess national-level impacts and implications for Saudi Arabia\'s carbon emission reduction goals. **Synergy factors: How does the project align with and contribute to national priority?** ***Targeted priority under the call for grants: Energy and Industrial leadership - Achieve net-zero emissions by 2060***

The project on smart grid implementation in the Asir region aligns with and contributes to Saudi Arabia's national priority of achieving net-zero emissions by 2060 in several ways, as evidenced by the provided context:

  1. Energy Efficiency and Demand Management:

    • The project aims to optimize electricity production, distribution, and consumption through advanced technologies like AI-based forecasting and IoT-based monitoring systems [1a], [1b], [1c]. This aligns with the findings that energy efficiency measures and electricity price reforms can significantly reduce electricity demand in Saudi Arabia [1a], [1d], [1e].
    • The integration of smart grid technologies enables two-way communication between suppliers and consumers, promoting more efficient resource use and seamless integration of renewable energy sources [1b], [1c]. This is crucial for adapting production to demand in real time, reducing energy losses, and minimizing fossil fuel dependence [1f].

  2. Economic Implications:

    • The project will evaluate the economic implications of smart grid implementation through detailed cost-benefit analysis, assessment of investment models and funding mechanisms, and analysis of public-private partnership opportunities [1g], [1f]. This aligns with the potential macroeconomic gains from energy savings, which can alleviate some of the burden on public finance [1a], [1f].

  3. Environmental Impact:

    • The environmental impact assessment will quantify potential greenhouse gas reductions and model contributions to Saudi Arabia's NZE 2060 goals [1h], [1g]. This aligns with the findings that renewable-powered smart grids can lead to substantial CO₂ emissions reductions [1h], [1g].
    • The project will develop AI-powered energy management models to support the development of an efficient energy management system, which can help in achieving the national strategy to reform the energy sector [1g], [1f].

  4. Policy Recommendations:

    • The project will formulate policy recommendations for smart grid adoption frameworks, investment and funding mechanisms, and regional and national implementation strategies [1b], [1c], [1h]. This aligns with the need for policy adaptation and the importance of green finance mechanisms and public-private partnerships in funding smart grid projects [1h], [1g].

  5. Alignment with National Priorities:

    • The project's focus on the Asir region as a case study, with findings scaled to assess national-level impacts and implications for Saudi Arabia's carbon emission reduction goals, directly contributes to the targeted priority of achieving net-zero emissions by 2060 [1b], [1c], [1h].

In summary, the project's objectives and methodologies align with the national priority of achieving net-zero emissions by 2060 through enhanced energy efficiency, economic evaluation, environmental impact assessment, and policy recommendations. The integration of advanced technologies and the focus on both regional and national levels ensure that the project contributes to Saudi Arabia's energy transition strategy and carbon emission reduction goals.
